title: 113_s2399
content: The "Native Voting Rights Act of 2014" is also known as the Act. It addresses tribal identification and actions to address disparities in polling place availability. Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act is amended to allow tribal identification documents issued by Indian tribes to be treated as valid forms of identification for voting purposes. The Attorney General may take legal actions for declaratory judgment or injunctive relief if disparities in in-person voting opportunities are found. The Attorney General can take legal actions, including declaratory judgment or injunctive relief, if there is a disparity in in-person voting opportunities for members of an Indian tribe compared to non-members. Measures to reduce this disparity may include increasing the availability of polling places. Such actions will be heard by a court of three judges, with appeals going to the Supreme Court. The court of three judges will hear cases regarding disparities in voting opportunities for Indian tribe members. Appeals will go to the Supreme Court. An aggrieved person can bring an action despite certain limitations. PROTECTIONS RELATING TO POLLING PLACES ON INDIAN RESERVATIONS. Protections Relating to Indian Reservations under the Voting Rights Act of 1965 include requirements for approval before eliminating or moving polling places on reservations. Protections under the Voting Rights Act of 1965 include restrictions on moving or consolidating polling places on Indian reservations, eliminating in-person voting by designating reservations as permanent absentee voting locations, and reducing early voting opportunities on reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 prohibits reducing early voting opportunities on Indian reservations and restricts changes to in-person or early voting locations on reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 prohibits reducing early voting opportunities on Indian reservations and restricts changes to in-person or early voting locations on reservations. State or political subdivision must not enact any activities described in subsection (g) of section 4 after November 1, 1972, and must use the term "procedure, or activity" instead of "or procedure". Federal election oversight on Indian reservations is addressed in Section 4. Section 8 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow the Attorney General to authorize Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations if a written complaint is received regarding potential voter rights violations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations in response to complaints of potential voter rights violations based on race or color. SEC. 5 amends the Voting Rights Act of 1965 regarding the termination of election observers. It specifies the conditions for ending observer appointments after the next general election for the President. SEC. 6 provides definitions. SEC. 6 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 amends definitions related to Indian tribes and tribal organizations, as well as the definition of a member of an Indian tribe. SEC. 7 amends bilingual election requirements and the definition of Indian reservation under the Voting Rights Act of 1965. SEC. 8 requires the Attorney General to make reports of Federal election observers publicly available. SEC. 9 addresses tribal voting consultation. SEC. 9 requires the Attorney General to consult annually with tribal organizations on voting issues for members of an Indian tribe.
